Ilja, I think you were right.

Currently, I'm working on a simple parser an=
d evaluator. In this example, I have lot's of tests to verify the parsers c=
orrectness. When I write the tests for the evaluator, I want to use the par=
ser for setting up my fixture.
In this example, a failure of the parser cau=
ses the failure of the evaluator.

It would be nice to mark the evaluator-t=
ests to depend on the parser-tests. A failure of the parser only causes the=
 skipping of the evaluator-tests. This would ease the the search for the so=
urce.

If I try to reduce the complexity of a method, it usually only resul=
ts in some private (and thereby untestable) methods.

Bye,
  Stefan

Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:
> 
>> In my not so humble opinion, a =
complex method is a serious design smell
> 
> For unit tests, yes. For inte=
gration/functional tests, it's pretty common.

Oh. I thought that Stefan wa=
s talking about a complex *production* 
method that he wanted to test, not =
a complex test method.

Cheers, Ilja
